title: 111_s928
content: The "TARP Accountability Act of 2009" requires enhanced reporting on the use of TARP funds. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to include detailed reporting requirements for financial institutions regarding the use of TARP funds. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 now includes reporting requirements for financial institutions on the use of TARP funds, including details on fund usage, retention for recapitalization, expected future use, compliance with restrictions on dividends, stock repurchases, and executive compensation. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 includes reporting requirements for financial institutions receiving funds from the Capital Purchase Program. Financial institutions must provide information to the Treasury on fund usage, compliance with restrictions, and executive compensation. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 mandates reporting requirements for financial institutions participating in the Capital Purchase Program. They must provide monthly lending and intermediation snapshots, including quantitative information and commentary on changes in lending levels for consumer and commercial lending categories. The reporting requirements for financial institutions participating in the Capital Purchase Program include quantitative information and commentary on changes in lending levels for various categories, such as commercial and industrial lending, real estate, mortgage-backed securities, and asset-backed securities. Additionally, a narrative report on intermediation activity during the reporting period is required, covering the lending environment, loan demand, changes in lending standards and terms, and other intermediation activities. Financial institutions receiving less than $1 billion from the Capital Purchase Program must provide lending and intermediation snapshots every 90 days, signed by a senior executive officer certifying the accuracy of the information. Financial institutions receiving less than $1 billion from the Capital Purchase Program must provide lending and intermediation snapshots every 90 days, signed by a senior executive officer certifying the accuracy of the information, which will be included in the reports submitted by the Secretary.
